DOC.HEAD: Noriega Records May Help Trace Drug Money
DOC.TEXT: Financial records found in Manuel Antonio Noriega's offices may help investigators trace money the deposed Panamanian leader earned from drug trafficking, the Justice Department said today. Department spokesman David Runkel said U.S. investigators are reviewing the records seized in Noriega's offices at the Panamanian Defense Forces headquarters. ``We believe there are assets and we are checking records to determine where those assets are currently located,'' Runkel said. ``We have been in contact with foreign governments and financial institutions as well as people here'' to trace the cash and other holdings that Noriega is believed to have amassed from his involvement in drug trafficking, Runkel said. Runkel said he had no information to specifically identify any assets either in this country or abroad. But the spokesman said two foreign governments, which he would not name, are currently assisting the Justice Department's efforts to trace and freeze Noriega's holdings. The Treasury Department also was participating in the effort to trace the assets, Runkel said. The records seized during the U.S. invasion might contain evidence that Noriega looted the Panamanian treasury too, he said. The records will be studied in Panama by officials of the new Panamanian government installed after the U.S. invasion, he said. If useful, the records would be turned over to federal prosecutors in Miami and Tampa, Fla., where Noriega faces drug trafficking charges. He is accused of pocketing $10 million by allowing Colombian drug lords to smuggle cocaine and marijuana through Panama to the United States. The search for Noriega's assets was stepped up as the White House announced that U.S. troops in Panama had found about 110 pounds of cocaine worth $1.25 million in the Panama City building where Noriega had an office. The cocaine was found during a ``floor-by-floor'' search of the building at Fort Amador, said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater.
